conclusion: To determine whether Car A is ahead of or behind Car B at t = 10 seconds, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph and calculate the distance traveled by each car up to that time.

The graph shows the velocity of Cars A and B over time. Car A has a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 0 to t = 30 seconds. Car B starts from rest and accelerates linearly, reaching 40 m/s at t = 20 seconds.

premise: Car A travels at a constant velocity of 40 m/s.
conclusion: Distance traveled by Car A from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds: Distance_A = Velocity_A × Time = 40 m/s × 10 s = 400 m
Car B accelerates uniformly from 0 to 40 m/s over 20 seconds. The velocity-time graph for Car B is a straight line from 0 to 40 m/s.

premise: The area under the graph from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds represents the distance traveled by Car B. The area under the graph is a triangle with base 10 seconds and height 20 m/s.
conclusion: Distance_B = 1/2 × Base × Height = 1/2 × 10 s × 20 m/s = 100 m

premise: At t = 10 seconds: Car A has traveled 400 meters. Car B has traveled 100 meters.
conclusion: Since Car A has traveled 400 meters and Car B has traveled only 100 meters at t = 10 seconds, Car A is ahead of Car B.
